TEXT.Italian: Forme di governo e Religioni preferite

TEXT.English:
[H1]Revolution[\H1][NEWLINE]by Jdog5000[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The goal[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This component allows sections of disgruntled empires to rise up together and demand changes or attempt to break away from the motherland. No matter what the source of the complaint, you will be given an option to either ignore the complaint or accept the cities demands. If their demands go unmet and situations deteriorate, the cities may give you an ultimatum and take up arms if you do not comply![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This component is intended to add realistic dynamics to the game, making keeping your cities and regions happy more important and challenging. Each city in your empire will have factors that make it want to stay and factors that make it want to rebel. If you cannot find a balance that keeps each of your cities happy, you will face revolts! Revolts come in many different styles, including requests to change civics, requests to change state religion, and demands for independence. No matter what the scenario, you will always be given choices when confronted with a rebellious city.[PARAGRAPH:2]This component has been updated to support Vassal states and other new features of Warlords. It also now incorporates most of the ideas from the prior Rebellion component. The AI logic appears bug free, but it's difficult to test all the human popup handling. However, it has undergone extensive testing and is in a good working state.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]More Details[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Each city has a Revolution Index, and when that index gets up towards 1000 they start to get restless. You will be warned whenever a city passes over 900 and about every 15 turns while it's in the danger zone, and once over 1000 it may instigate a revolution. Other nearby cities with rev indices over 600 can join in a revolution. If a city is unhappy, things are very similar but the minimum threshold for a revolution drops quickly with the number of unhappy citizens. There are several different Revolution styles and the situation in the Revolution instigating city determines the style. Many styles have peaceful and violent variants: denying a request will just agitate the city further, but denying a demand will lead to civil war![NEWLINE][NEWLINE]In order of precedence:[NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Return to or reform dominant culture:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities in which you don't have a majority culture will become increasing aggitated and may attempt to break away for cultural reasons. The instigator and nearby, similarly cultured cities will ask (peaceful) or demand (violent) to join or reform a dead rival. Denying this request will cause your relations with the rival to deteriorate, and they may choose to declare war![NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Religious differences:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities may ask for a change away from Theocracy or to Freedom of Religion, or to switch your state religion. They can also ask or demand independence for religious reasons.[NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Homeland revolutions:[COLOR_REVERT] Ask for various different civics. May ask for you to go on a crusade to capture your religion's holy city.[NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Colonial revolutions:[COLOR_REVERT] Ask for change to representative government. (Independence handled below)[NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Capital or majority of cities revolting:[COLOR_REVERT] Cities will ask for changes in away from repressive civics, or for some form of a say in the government. They can also ask or demand a change in ruler! If you're running a representative government, accepting their requests will mean facing election. If you are replaced, the game will automate some number of turns and then return control to you (this feature can be disabled). [NEWLINE][TAB][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Independence:[COLOR_REVERT] If none of these particular conditions apply, the cities will ask for or demand independence. They may request full independence or assume Vassal status.[PARAGRAPH:2]If you face civil war, the situation may become qui
te dier. Strong garrisons may be able to maintain some semblance of control in some of the revolting cities, but weaker garrisons may be run out of town and the revolutionaries will take the city. Your homeland will not be the same for generations if you face multiple revolting cities on the battlefield! In addition, rebellious cities that the rebels have not yet taken may turn out rebel reinforcements.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The Revolution Watch[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Clicking on the red fist button below the normal info buttons or pressing [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-W[\BOLD] in the game will open the Revolution Watch popup. This popup displays which of your cities is in danger of rebelling, thinking about rebelling, or happy with your empire. In each category, the cities are ordered with the most rebellious towards the top. In addition, cities whose local situation is deterioirating are shown in orange. For specific information on how your civ-wide policies or the local city situation are effecting the rebelliousness of the city, scroll down and click the details button. This will open a new popup containing a lot of important information about the rebelliousness of your cities.[PARAGRAPH:2]At the top of this detail popup is an analysis of your national policies and situation. The effect of your civics, anarchy, golden age, empire size and fiscal situation are shown here. These affect all of your cities equally. Next is a city by city listing of local effects. The location of the city, the religions and cultures in the city, the happiness and healthiness of the people, the size of the city, the size of the city's garrison, and culture rate are all important factors you may see here. For both positive and negative effects the specific causes are ordered with the strongest first and grayscale indicating the intensity with whiter being more intense.[PARAGRAPH:2]Your civics can have a significant effect on how these local factors are felt. For example, running a theocracy will cause cities with non-state religions to be more rebellious, but keep cities with your state religion less rebellious. Representative government civics will greatly decrease the effects of distance on outlieing cities or colonies.

TEXT.English: [H1]How to Use AI Autoplay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This component is a tool, you decide when you want to activate it and for how long. Press [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-X[\BOLD] to open the AIAutoPlay Chooser window, select a number of turns to auto play and select Full Automation from the drop down menu (or no automation). There is a new feature to have the AI only move your units. At the start of your turn, change whatever you want or move a couple units, then press [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-M[\BOLD] to have the AI do the rest of that turn. You can also cancel automation by pressing [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-X[\BOLD] again, but only when there are no popups open. To help with that, there is a config option to block some standard game popups. [PARAGRAPH:2]In addition, there is a config option that will fortify all units fortified by the AI at the end of automation. Without this all units start active, although refortified units will not lose their defense percentage. [PARAGRAPH:2]Great for debugging or watching the behavior of the AI, as it shows you only what the AI can see. Also, if you want to skip certain sections of the game, or you're so close to winning but not quite there, let the AI play it for you! With many civs in the late game, auto play will still take a while but you won't have to do anything... it will basically take (number of turns)x(in between turn lag + a little bit) to go through the turns.

TEXT.German: [H1]How to Use AI Autoplay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This component is a tool, you decide when you want to activate it and for how long. Press [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-X[\BOLD] to open the AIAutoPlay Chooser window, select a number of turns to auto play and select Full Automation from the drop down menu (or no automation). There is a new feature to have the AI only move your units. At the start of your turn, change whatever you want or move a couple units, then press [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-M[\BOLD] to have the AI do the rest of that turn. You can also cancel automation by pressing [BOLD]Ctrl-Shift-X[\BOLD] again, but only when there are no popups open. To help with that, there is a config option to block some standard game popups. [PARAGRAPH:2]In addition, there is a config option that will fortify all units fortified by the AI at the end of automation. Without this all units start active, although refortified units will not lose their defense percentage. [PARAGRAPH:2]Great for debugging or watching the behavior of the AI, as it shows you only what the AI can see. Also, if you want to skip certain sections of the game, or you're so close to winning but not quite there, let the AI play it for you! With many civs in the late game, auto play will still take a while but you won't have to do anything... it will basically take (number of turns)x(in between turn lag + a little bit) to go through the turns.

TEXT.English:
[H1]BarbarianCiv[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The goal:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In this mod, barbarian cities, if left to their own devices, will eventually settle down into full blown civs![PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Barbarian cities will settle down probabilistically, with several factor determining the odds. Starting with version 2.0, barb cities first become single city minor civs. These city states can't conduct diplomacy, so they're at war with everyone. When the new civ accomplishes something notable, a leader emerges and the civ settles down into a full civ. These accomplishments can include conquest, reaching a high population, reaching a high level of culture, building wonders, etc. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]More details:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The decision to have a barbarian city form a minor civ is based on the population and culture of the city, whether there are nearby civs, and whether the city was captured. When a minor civ forms, they take control of this single city and are given some units and techs to get started. Since they are a minor civ they're at war with everyone else and cannot conduct diplomacy, so you won't see them on the scoreboard. [PARAGRAPH:2]Each turn the minor civs are checked to see if they deserve to be upgraded to full civ status. When settling down into a full civ, these minor civs will take on one of two types: militaristic and builder. If they have conquered a city, they will immediately settle into a full, militaristic civ and continue the war against whomever they took a city from. If they have reached a high level of culture or built a wonder, they will settle as builders. If they settle due to high population or founding a religion, they have a probabilistic chance of being one or the other. [PARAGRAPH:2]The civs get several bonuses depending on whether they're militaristic or builder. Both types get a base set of defensive units and workers, plus some free techs known to a majority of the world. The new civ also gets a great person (to symbolize the leader who organized the horde), with the GP type depending on the type of consolidation. Their capital is given walls and a granary. If the cities have some culture, the new civ gets half of the total. These general effects for both types of rise of the barbs are intended to partly catch them up with the rest of the world. [PARAGRAPH:2]Militaristic consolidation is the most exciting in my view. It's intended to mimic the effect of Ghengis Khan or the Vikings. There are four different flavors of militaristic settling, Viking, Chariot, Horse, and balanced. Vikings get boats and mostly melee units, Chariot style is for earlier barb settling and they get chariots and some axes, Horse style is mostly Horse archers or Knights if late enough, while balanced gets an assortment of units. The strength of the military is fairly random, and increases as the eras go by. Odds of a militaristic build up increase if the new leader is Aggressive or Expansionist. Militaristic new civs will be behind in economic or social technology. They also get free barracks. Militaristic barbs have a good chance of getting a Great General when spawned. [PARAGRAPH:2]Builder consolidation is intended to mimic the rise of a new civ that isn't particularly militaristic. This type of civ gets additional techs, one or two of which they may be the first to research. They are given a Great Person and may build a wonder or discover a new tech. It's not uncommon for them to found a new religion. They are also given a bunch of extra infrastructure: extra worker, free settler, and some buildings like libraries, lighthouses, and forges (if they have the tech).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Notes on use:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]To make this component more exciting, the amount of Barbarian activity has generally been increased. Particularly, barbarian cities will form both earlier and more often to help this component fill in empty space in the game map with new players. With this change, a full standard map game will probably see a handful of barb civs emerge. [PARAGRAPH:2]On
e fun one to play is start a large world with only a handful of civs, then let the barbarians fill in the gaps. Be prepared for a potential invasion from a rising power! BarbarianCiv also works quite well with the Revolution component that can spawn barbarian rebels. [PARAGRAPH:2]On Terra maps, the new world will probably not be as empty as before. A new config variable, NewWorldPolicy, can be used to define how barb cities on their own continent behave so that you can customize how the new world will appear when the first explorers land. Options range from having it mostly full of civs to keeping barb cities as barbarian until someone starts colonizing.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are many other settings in the Revolution.ini config file, including MilitaryStrength which can be used to create massive military invasions and modifiers for controlling the odds of civ formation.

TEXT.English: [H1]Tech Diffusion[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The goal:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]With this component, civs who fall behind in tech but have lots of friends will receive some free research.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When a civ falls behind by several techs, they qualify for tech "welfare." Each turn that they are significantly behind, they will receive some free beakers towards techs they can research. The amount of free beakers depends on how many civs they know who already have the tech and what there relationships are, although the rate for powerful military techs is lowered since civs try harder to keep them secret. If a civ is behind by a handful of techs, they will get fractions of a percent of the research per turn. If they are behind by a dozen or more, the rate increases.[PARAGRAPH:2]The diffusion of tech is capped so that civs don't receive techs for free but have to do the final research push themselves. The cap is low in the early eras, and moves up as the eras go on. If a civ is very far behind, the cap is ignored to try and keep them somewhat in the game.

Each turn that they are significantly behind, they will receive some free beakers towards techs they can research. The amount of free beakers depends on how many civs they know who already have the tech and what there relationships are, although the rate for powerful military techs is lowered since civs try harder to keep them secret. If a civ is behind by a handful of techs, they will get fractions of a percent of the research per turn. If they are behind by a dozen or more, the rate increases.[PARAGRAPH:2]The diffusion of tech is capped so that civs don't receive techs for free but have to do the final research push themselves. The cap is low in the early eras, and moves up as the eras go on. If a civ is very far behind, the cap is ignored to try and keep them somewhat in the game.

TEXT.English: [H1]Dynamic Civ Names[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]The goal:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This component renames civs based on their civics choices and other status factors. A civs names will change many times over the course of a game. While it has no actual effect on gameplay, it adds dynamic variety to the game.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How it works:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When a civ is created or changes their civics, they are potentially assigned a new name based on many factors. Civs spawned by either Revolution or BarbarianCiv will get temporary names indicating their status, like Mongolian Horde or Russian Rebels, until they're more firmly established. When a civ switches to Hereditary Rule their name will change to something like Kingdom of America, while under Representation or Universal Sufferage they would be the American Republic. Civs with only one city in the later stages of the game may have the city name included in their title, but their civ type will always be clarified as in the French Kingom of Paris. Vassals will also get different names. There are many different potential names, and even variations for civs with the same status to provide some flavor.[PARAGRAPH:2]All of the civics determinations are made using the added Revolution flags in the civics xml file to support variations on the standard civics systems. Having a civic with the isCommunism bool set will cause Communist style names. In addition, some civs have special names like show up in certain circumstances, like the German Reich and Arabian Caliphate. These determinations are made by matching text in the civs adjective (ie German or Arabian).[PARAGRAPH:2]This component has several features designed to support names of civs created by BarbarianCiv and Revolution, but would provide plenty of fun flavor name changes as a standalone mod or addition for other mods. It requires changes to the DLL to allow name changes to stick, but all name changes are generated in Python.

TEXT.English: [H1]Ethnic Citystyles[\H1][NEWLINE]by Geomodder[PARAGRAPH:2]This mod is made to make the civilizations more culturally diverse with the available art made by freelance modders and unused art by Firaxis.[PARAGRAPH:2]Basically, citysets of the different artstyle groups have been changed/altered until the Modern Era, where ever art was available for it. The future era has been made common for all artstyles. In some cases you'll still see the normal ingame cityset buildings, which means I haven't found art for those spots or I intended it to remain there. Also, for some units and buildings new .dds files are included which I felt made them look better without altering the basic model of it.[PARAGRAPH:2]Besides citystyles, new facility art has been included for the different artstyles. This part is not finished yet since there's no art available for some artstyles/era's. Included are Sepamu92's fishingboat modcomponent and art has been replaced for some improvements too.[PARAGRAPH:2]The new artstyles in this mod so far are AFRICA, ANGLO AMERICA, ARABIA, ASIA, BARBARIAN, CRESCENT, EGYPT, EUROPE, GRECO_ROMAN, IBERIA, INDIA, JAPAN, MESO AMERICA, MONGOLIA, NATIVE AMERICA, NORSE, RUSSIA, SOUTH AMERICA and SOUTH-EAST ASIA. Don't expect truly different citystyles in all cases tho, quite a number of them are hybrids, especially the Indian -and Khmer civ. The main new thing is that from the Industrial era on a mix of old and new city buildings are used. For instance in the Modern era you'll see Industrial city art and modern flats mixed for the European civs.

TEXT.English: [H1]Enhanced Tech Conquest[\H1][NEWLINE]by Grave, Jeckel[PARAGRAPH:2]The Enhanced Tech Conquest Mod is designed to give a tech boost from conquering enemy cities. When an enemy city is conquered, a list of techs the enemy has that your empire doesn't is created. From that list a random tech is selected.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Gameplay[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Captured cities always give a minimum of 25 percent towards the cost of a tech plus a random amount[PARAGRAPH:2]The random amount is from 0 to (city size * 5) percent. For example a city of size 4 would give between 25% and 45% of the tech cost. This assumes the default configuration values have not been changed[PARAGRAPH:2]Cities greater than size 15 increase the chance of getting a full tech. For example a city of size 20 would give between 25 and 125 percent of the tech cost. This assumes the default configuration value has not been changed.[PARAGRAPH:2]Several configurable options (Rise of mankind config.ini) allow tuning of how technology will get transfered from the conquered city to the conquering civilization.

TEXT.English: [H1]Inquisition[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]While the missionary seeks to spread the state religion, the Inquisitor is used to remove all non-state religions from a city. Like the Missionary, the inquisitor is limited to a maximum of only 3 units a player can have at any one time. As the defender of the official state religious faith, the inquisitor is a very powerful unit. If an inquisition is successful, all non-state religions and their associated non-state religious buildings will be removed from the city. Whether the inquisition is successful or not, the unit is used up after executing an inquisition. Thus, the production of many inquisitors may be necessary to finally achieve religious unity. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Foreign Inquisitions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You can also conduct a foreign inquisition, if you meet all 3 prerequisites below. [PARAGRAPH:2]To build an inquisitor: You must have researched Fundamantalism, have a state religion in the city and have Intolerant religion civic active.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a city: You must have your state religion previously established in a city and there must be at least one non-state religion established in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a foreign city: The foreign civilization must have the same state religion as you, the foreign civilization must have an open borders agreement with you and the foreign city must also meet the requirements of prerequisite 2 above. [PARAGRAPH:2]If you want to play a game with Limited Religions, then simply enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Respawn Holy Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Respawn a Holy City that was purged by an inquisitor or razed during wars. By default this feature is off but you can enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Purging Holy Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This game feature allows Inquisitors to purge Holy Cities which means that if the city has non-state religion Holy City and you purge the city with Inquisitor the non-state religious holy city is removed. This feature is off by default. If you want to use this feature you can enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).

[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Foreign Inquisitions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You can also conduct a foreign inquisition, if you meet all 3 prerequisites below. [PARAGRAPH:2]To build an inquisitor: You must have researched Fundamantalism, have a state religion in the city and have Intolerant religion civic active.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a city: You must have your state religion previously established in a city and there must be at least one non-state religion established in the same city.[PARAGRAPH:2]To use an inquisitor in a foreign city: The foreign civilization must have the same state religion as you, the foreign civilization must have an open borders agreement with you and the foreign city must also meet the requirements of prerequisite 2 above. [PARAGRAPH:2]If you want to play a game with Limited Religions, then simply enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Respawn Holy Cities[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Respawn a Holy City that was purged by an inquisitor or razed during wars. This feature is off by default. If you want to use this feature you can enable it from RevDCM options page in BUG Options (CTRL-ALT-O).

TEXT.English:
[H1]Influence Driven War[\H1][NEWLINE]by Moctezuma[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Military units affect surroundings via combat influence:[PARAGRAPH:2]After each combat between two units: some amount of culture accumulated in each square of combat area is transferred from loser player/AI to winner player/AI. Combat area (i.e. influence radius) is: attacker plot, defended plot and near surrounding plots (see definition of influence radius bellow). Note: This way I try to simulate effect of battle victory: some peoples have tendency to give up and flip to victorious side.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rules:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works for both field battle and city assault.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works for both attacking and defending (also city defending).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If last defending unit in city dies: combat influence is increased greatly (an emergency militia may be "auto-drafted", check new resistance rules later).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If victorious unit has warlord: combat influence is increased.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If attacking unit withdraws: no culture transfer happens.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Calculated culture exchange cannot be higher than loser's remaining culture in plot. This means that no culture transfer happens in empty neutral territory: nobody is living there to be influenced. In third-party territory a culture transfer occurs only if some loser's culture is accumulated there.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works also for attacking/defending barbarians in player or barbarian territory (this can be disabled via XML file).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Also water squares are affected by combat influence.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Naval combats use same influence rules as land combats. Note: if naval battle occurs near land, also land squares are affected (naval influence can be disabled via XML file).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]No culture is exchanged during city bombardment (via catapults, ships, bombers, ICBM); during fighter interception; or if worker/settler is captured out of city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Active city resistance[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If last defending unit in the city dies and city resistance is sufficient then one militia unit emerges in city, otherwise it is captured just like in vanilla. Resistance is sufficient if defender's culture in central plot is same or higher than attacker's culture in central plot (culture ratios in central city plot you can check also in the city screen). Note: This new rule tries to simulate active people resistance in highly cultured cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Militia unit is "auto-drafted":[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Best available regular unit type is selected using same rules as for standard drafting: i.e. warrior, axeman, maceman, musketman, rifleman...[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Auto-drafted unit begins with 25% health (configurable in XML). This represents very low training level of quickly gathered militia.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Draft anger is 50% of standard draft anger: high danger means low anger. (configurable in XML)[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]City population is reduced by 1 (it doesn't depend on unit type).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Auto-draft is not limited like standard draft: new militia unit is "auto-drafted" when previous one dies and resistance is still sufficient.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When city population is reduced to 1, the city is captured even if resistance is still sufficient.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]There is no technology requirement for auto-draft: this is not real conscription: imagine peoples that are just trying in defend their homes.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It takes some time to accumulate sufficient culture: if city is attacked early no militia emerges.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pillage influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When enemy unit pillages tile improvement, some amount of accumulated culture is transferred from improvement owner to unit owner. Only single square is affected. [PARAGRAPH:2]Note: This rule was added to provide incentive for defender to defend own territory and
not only stay inside cities. It reflects situation where farmers, miners or villagers escape due to farm, mine or village is burned down by invader. [PARAGRAPH:2]This rule is optional and can be disabled via XML.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rules:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works only in enemy territory (no influence in friendly or neutral territory)[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]No influence form route pillage (roads, railroads).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Works also for sea improvements (e.g. fishing boats).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]For improvements like towns, each downgrade influences given square.[PARAGRAPH:2][H1]Gameplay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Player is informed about effects of IDW this way:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]After each battle a number with influence % (i.e. exchanged culture ratio) is shown in the game log. It is calculated in defended plot only, but whole combat area is influenced. Reason that I'm using defended plot here is because it is in most cases the most important one (e.g. central city square).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Green color means culture increase for you[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Red color means culture decrease for you.[PARAGRAPH:2]When last city defender dies and militia unit is "auto-drafted" a remaining resistance % is shown in the game log.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Result of changes on gameplay:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]1. More dynamic borders during wars:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In vanilla game a culture plays significant role only in the beginning. In later stages the borders are almost fixed: big changes happen only if cities are captured. [PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules you can fight for territory between cities and not only for cities itself. I think that this "frontline" effect really improves gameplay. You can "win" quite large area with several resources even without conquering single enemy city! Possible tactics if you dont have sufficient power to conquer cities could be stay/pillage/heal near your borders and influence squares by killing approaching enemies.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]2. Surprise or backstabbing attacks are less effective:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Attacked city can for short time defend itself even if last defender dies if resistance is sufficient: this increases reaction time for defending player if he has many units in the opposite side of empire.[PARAGRAPH:2]However you cannot count on auto-drafted units. These are meant only to slow-down attack in case when everything else fails. In most cases a militia units can defend high cultured city only 1-2 turns until real defender units arrive because: [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Militia unit begins with very low health, so if it is attacked in same turn, it almost certainly dies.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]City resistance decreases very quickly because victory influence is much higher when last city defender dies (see NoCityDefenderMultiplier).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Each auto-drafted unit increases unhappiness in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: I cannot make militia units more effective, because then player can abuse it: e.g. move out all defenders from city and later counterattack damaged attackers.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]3. High cultured cities are harder to conquer (more militia formed) but easier to hold after capture [\BOLD]because city's central square has quite good amount of conquerors culture immediately after capture.[PARAGRAPH:2]This means:[PARAGRAPH:2]No problem with cultural flipping of captured city back to original owner: In vanilla is this problem is fixed by disabling startup option: "City flipping after conquest". This is no longer needed in this mod.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much smaller problem with cultural flipping of captured city to neighbor civ, which can be in peace with conqueror. Naturally, if just conquered city has been in big cultural pressure prior to capture it will be in pressure also after it, because culture is transferred only from city's previous owner.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: culture buildings in newly captured city are still very important because city still begins with zero culture (only plots are influenced by combat).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]4.
No problems with stealing of conquered city:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This happens often in multiplayer with simultaneous turns but sometimes it occurs also in single-player: Two players are doing joint attack on same enemy city; first player destroys all defenders; second one just waits until last defender remains there and then attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the city capture is fairer: culture in central city square is increased after each victory for each attacking player separately. If no defender unit is left then attacker, whose culture in central square is higher than owners culture, captures the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]5. In battles quality counts more than quantity:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the conquest is easier with smaller stack of high strength units than with bigger stack of low strength units: Veteran unit makes more influence (see UnitExperienceMultiplier) and better victory/loss ratio means more culture transferred to attacker.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some examples:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Suicide catapults are little less effective: due to losses, defender's culture increases more often.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Blitz units like tanks are very effective: due to multiple culture exchanges per turn. This really speeds up the conquest of very highly cultured cities in later stages of game, which can be really slow otherwise.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Warlord units are more effective than normal units (see WarlordMultiplier).

In most cases a militia units can defend high cultured city only 1-2 turns until real defender units arrive because: [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Militia unit begins with very low health, so if it is attacked in same turn, it almost certainly dies.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]City resistance decreases very quickly because victory influence is much higher when last city defender dies (see NoCityDefenderMultiplier).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Each auto-drafted unit increases unhappiness in the city.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: I cannot make militia units more effective, because then player can abuse it: e.g. move out all defenders from city and later counterattack damaged attackers.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]3. High cultured cities are harder to conquer (more militia formed) but easier to hold after capture [\BOLD]because city's central square has quite good amount of conquerors culture immediately after capture.[PARAGRAPH:2]This means:[PARAGRAPH:2]No problem with cultural flipping of captured city back to original owner: In vanilla is this problem is fixed by disabling startup option: "City flipping after conquest". This is no longer needed in this mod.[PARAGRAPH:2]Much smaller problem with cultural flipping of captured city to neighbor civ, which can be in peace with conqueror. Naturally, if just conquered city has been in big cultural pressure prior to capture it will be in pressure also after it, because culture is transferred only from city's previous owner.[PARAGRAPH:2]Note: culture buildings in newly captured city are still very important because city still begins with zero culture (only plots are influenced by combat).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]4.
No problems with stealing of conquered city:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This happens often in multiplayer with simultaneous turns but sometimes it occurs also in single-player: Two players are doing joint attack on same enemy city; first player destroys all defenders; second one just waits until last defender remains there and then attacks.[PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the city capture is fairer: culture in central city square is increased after each victory for each attacking player separately. If no defender unit is left then attacker, whose culture in central square is higher than owners culture, captures the city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]5. In battles quality counts more than quantity:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules the conquest is easier with smaller stack of high strength units than with bigger stack of low strength units: Veteran unit makes more influence (see UnitExperienceMultiplier) and better victory/loss ratio means more culture transferred to attacker.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Some examples:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Suicide catapults are little less effective: due to losses, defender's culture increases more often.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Blitz units like tanks are very effective: due to multiple culture exchanges per turn. This really speeds up the conquest of very highly cultured cities in later stages of game, which can be really slow otherwise.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Warlord units are more effective than normal units (see WarlordMultiplier).
TEXT.Italian:
[H1]Influence Driven War[\H1][NEWLINE]by Moctezuma[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Combat influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Military units affect surroundings via combat influence:[PARAGRAPH:2]After each combat between two units: some amount of culture accumulated in each square of combat area is transferred from loser player/AI to winner player/AI. Combat area (i.e. influence radius) is: attacker plot, defended plot and near surrounding plots (see definition of influence radius bellow). Note: This way I try to simulate effect of battle victory: some peoples have tendency to give up and flip to victorious side.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rules:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works for both field battle and city assault.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works for both attacking and defending (also city defending).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If last defending unit in city dies: combat influence is increased greatly (an emergency militia may be "auto-drafted", check new resistance rules later).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If victorious unit has warlord: combat influence is increased.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If attacking unit withdraws: no culture transfer happens.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Calculated culture exchange cannot be higher than loser's remaining culture in plot. This means that no culture transfer happens in empty neutral territory: nobody is living there to be influenced. In third-party territory a culture transfer occurs only if some loser's culture is accumulated there.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works also for attacking/defending barbarians in player or barbarian territory (this can be disabled via XML file).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Also water squares are affected by combat influence.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Naval combats use same influence rules as land combats. Note: if naval battle occurs near land, also land squares are affected (naval influence can be disabled via XML file).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]No culture is exchanged during city bombardment (via catapults, ships, bombers, ICBM); during fighter interception; or if worker/settler is captured out of city.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Active city resistance[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If last defending unit in the city dies and city resistance is sufficient then one militia unit emerges in city, otherwise it is captured just like in vanilla. Resistance is sufficient if defender's culture in central plot is same or higher than attacker's culture in central plot (culture ratios in central city plot you can check also in the city screen). Note: This new rule tries to simulate active people resistance in highly cultured cities.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Militia unit is "auto-drafted":[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Best available regular unit type is selected using same rules as for standard drafting: i.e. warrior, axeman, maceman, musketman, rifleman...[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Auto-drafted unit begins with 25% health (configurable in XML). This represents very low training level of quickly gathered militia.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Draft anger is 50% of standard draft anger: high danger means low anger. (configurable in XML)[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]City population is reduced by 1 (it doesn't depend on unit type).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Auto-draft is not limited like standard draft: new militia unit is "auto-drafted" when previous one dies and resistance is still sufficient.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When city population is reduced to 1, the city is captured even if resistance is still sufficient.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]There is no technology requirement for auto-draft: this is not real conscription: imagine peoples that are just trying in defend their homes.[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It takes some time to accumulate sufficient culture: if city is attacked early no militia emerges.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Pillage influence[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]When enemy unit pillages tile improvement, some amount of accumulated culture is transferred from improvement owner to unit owner. Only single square is affected. [PARAGRAPH:2]Note: This rule was added to provide incentive for defender to defend own territory and
not only stay inside cities. It reflects situation where farmers, miners or villagers escape due to farm, mine or village is burned down by invader. [PARAGRAPH:2]This rule is optional and can be disabled via XML.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Rules:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]It works only in enemy territory (no influence in friendly or neutral territory)[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]No influence form route pillage (roads, railroads).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Works also for sea improvements (e.g. fishing boats).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]For improvements like towns, each downgrade influences given square.[PARAGRAPH:2][H1]Gameplay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Player is informed about effects of IDW this way:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]After each battle a number with influence % (i.e. exchanged culture ratio) is shown in the game log. It is calculated in defended plot only, but whole combat area is influenced. Reason that I'm using defended plot here is because it is in most cases the most important one (e.g. central city square).[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Green color means culture increase for you[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Red color means culture decrease for you.[PARAGRAPH:2]When last city defender dies and militia unit is "auto-drafted" a remaining resistance % is shown in the game log.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Result of changes on gameplay:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]1. More dynamic borders during wars:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]In vanilla game a culture plays significant role only in the beginning. In later stages the borders are almost fixed: big changes happen only if cities are captured. [PARAGRAPH:2]With new rules you can fight for territory between cities and not only for cities itself. I think that this "frontline" effect really improves gameplay. You can "win" quite large area with several resources even without conquering single enemy city! TEXT.English: [H1]Building Upgrade Lines[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind introduces building upgrade lines which lets you upgrade your old buildings to newer and better once you have founded new technologies. Upgraded buildings have the effects of the previous building and some new effects. The old building is removed from the city. When city is conquered and some of its buildings are destroyed, you'll have to start the upgrade paths again from the first building.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Upgrade lines are:[NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Harbor upgrades to Port, then to Commecrial Port and finally to International Port[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]River Port upgrades to Harbor. Note that you can build River Port also in cities that are nearby river but aren't coastal. In these cities River Port can't be upgraded (ships can not travel rivers).[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Walls upgrade to High Walls[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Granary upgrades to Modern Granary[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Bakery upgrades to Food Processing Plant[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Forge upgrades to Steel Mill[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Airport upgrades to Commercial Airport[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Toll House upgrades to Customs House[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Shipyard upgrades to Drydock[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Arcology upgrades to Arcology Shielding and finally to Advanced Shielding. Building Arcology also obsoletes Anti-Missile Batteries which is removed from city

TEXT.English: [H1]Specialist Stacker[\H1][NEWLINE]by TheLopez and modified by Ruff_hi[PARAGRAPH:2]This mod "stacks" the specialized citizens, super specialized citizens and angry citizens instead of displaying them side-by-side. It also makes use of the space to the left of the specialized citizens by allowing them to span into two columns instead of just one. This will allow for more than the vanilla six specialized citizens to exist in the game.

TEXT.English: [H1]Civ4lerts[\H1][NEWLINE]by Dr. Elmer Jiggles (Heavily Modified by EmperorFool) [PARAGRAPH:2]This mod implements on screen alerts for a variety of in-game events such as city growth and the availability of new trade opportunities. The concept is modeled after the CivAssist tool for Civilization 3, and in fact, many of the alerts are the same. [PARAGRAPH:2]The alerts will not reveal information that would otherwise be unavailable. They are simply intended to call the player's attention to situations as they arise without requiring tedious scanning of the advisor screens on each turn.[PARAGRAPH:2]The alert messages are integrated with the existing event log. Like those messages, a notification is displayed on screen for a short period of time. Messages that have been cleared from the screen can be recalled by opening the event log. When appropriate, clicking on a message brings the camera focus to the site of the event. [PARAGRAPH:2]The Alerts you can set up are:[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Cities:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pending Growth [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed the turn before city growth.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Growth [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed when a city grows.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pending Healthiness [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed the turn before city becomes unhealthy. [PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Healthiness[COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed when a city grows unhealthy.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pending Happiness [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed the turn before city becomes unhappy. [PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Happiness [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed when a city grows unhappy.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Pending Border Expansion [COLOR_REVERT]- Alert displayed the turn before a cities cultural borders will expand.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Can Hurry w. Population [COLOR_REVERT]- Can use population to hurry the production of a city, as well as how many population points it will take, and the amount of hammers of overflow.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Can Hurry W. Gold [COLOR_REVERT]- Can hurry the production of a city with cash, and how much it will cost.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacy:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Open Border [COLOR_REVERT]- Will sign Open Borders Agreement.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Defensive Pact [COLOR_REVERT]- Will sign Defensive Pact [PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Permanent Alliance [COLOR_REVERT]- Will sign Permanent Alliance [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Trading:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Technologies[COLOR_REVERT]- What technologies other civilizations will trade.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Gold [COLOR_REVERT]- When other civilizations have Gold available for trade. You can set the minimum amount of gold before the alert is triggers as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Gold Per Turn [COLOR_REVERT]- When other civilizations have Gold Per Turn available for trade. You can set the minimum amount of gold before the alert is triggers as well.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Victory:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Domination Limit: Population [COLOR_REVERT]- When you are about to win a Domination Victory for Population. You can set the percentage away from that limit before the alert is triggered.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Domination Limit: Land [COLOR_REVERT]When you are about to win a Domination Victory for Land. You can set the percentage away from that limit before the alert is triggered.[PARAGRAPH:2]From the BUG Options Screen, in the Alerts Tab, you can check the alerts you want, or don't want, to be shown at the start of every turn.

TEXT.English: [H1]Better Espionage Screen [\H1][NEWLINE]by Almighty Theo (Heavily Modified by EmperorFool) [PARAGRAPH:2]Better Espionage Screen allows for more civilizations to be shown within the Espionage Screen, as well as vital information being color coded. From within the BUG Options Screen you can turn off color coding for ratios, as well as revert back to the original version of the Espionage Screen.

TEXT.English: [H1]Cultural and Great Person Turns[\H1][NEWLINE]by Chinese American [PARAGRAPH:2]This will add a bar to the City View that will show many turns are left until Culture will expand in the current city screen, as well as turns to a Great Person in the city screen. You can turn off these bars from within the BUG Options Screen, under the General Tab.

TEXT.English: [H1]Great General Progress Bar[\H1][NEWLINE]by EmperorFool [PARAGRAPH:2]The Great General Progress Bar adds a bar below your Technology Research bar that tells you how many turns until your next Great General. If in wide screen mode it will display to the left of the Research bar. One thing to note is the display of the bar will not automatically update after a battle, but you must enter a screen and exit out for it to display properly. From within The BUG Options Screen, on the General Tab, you can turn the Great General Bar on or off.

TEXT.English: [H1]City Cycle Arrows[\H1][NEWLINE]by SimCutie[PARAGRAPH:2]This Mod will allow you to cycle through your cities from the Main Interface screen. Above your minimap in the Main Interface screen are a white left and right arrow. Clicking one of them will do a single-click action (pulling up city information in main interface, without detailed citizen information,) on the closest city in the main view.

TEXT.English: [H1]Improved Glance Tab[\H1][NEWLINE]by ruff_hi[PARAGRAPH:2]With version 3.13 of Beyond the Sword, the Glance Screen within the Advisor Screen was removed for, "being to ugly." We felt the information given in this screen was vital, and so returned it to the Foreign Advisor screen, but improved. We realigned the grid, as well as adding the attitude icons, and color coding the modifiers. It should now be easier to see where you stand with your rivals.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Instructions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Go to the Foreign Advisor Screen from the Main Interface, and click on Glance.

TEXT.English: [H1]Great Person Technology Preferences[\H1][NEWLINE]by EmperorFool [PARAGRAPH:2]This mod provides an enhanced version of the Technology Chooser screen (F6). Along the bottom of the screen you will see five groups of three icons; each group consists of a great person icon and two technology icons. For each great person icon, the left technology icon shows which technology that great person will research given the technologies you have already researched. The right technology icon shows which technology they will research once you have researched all the technologies you have selected in the screen. Once a great person has no more technologies that it can research, it will show a red circle with a line through it for its technology icons; this is the same symbol used for "No State Religion".[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Instructions[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]You can enable or disable this mod using the BUG Options screen's (Ctrl-Alt-O) General tab. Simply toggle the "Great Person Research" check box in the first column.

TEXT.English: [H1]BUG Military Advisor[\H1][NEWLINE]by Ruff_hi and EmperorFool [PARAGRAPH:2]The Military Advisor is now divided into two sections, Deployment, and the Sit-Rep (or Situation Report).[PARAGRAPH:2]The Deployment tab makes finding units easier by grouping units by location and unit type.[PARAGRAPH:2]The Sit-Rep tab is your all-in-one spot to find information related to your warmonging diplomacy. It displays the follow information:[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Icon for each Civilization in the game.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]A fist indicating that the Civilization "Has Enough on Their Hands", which usually means they are planning, or are engaged in a war that is taking all their resources.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]An icon display who the Civilzations Worst Enemy is.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]A Threat Indicator. This is not perfect, but gives you a rough idea what the threat level of attack from that civilization is towards you.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]Columns showing Strategic Advantages, both yours and the other civlizations. This is useful so you don't go attacking rifles with swordsman![PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]An indicator for if that civilization is a vassal of another.[PARAGRAPH:2][ICON_BULLET]An indicator if the civilization has a defensive pact.

TEXT.English: [H1]Not Just Another Game Clock[\H1][NEWLINE]by TheLopez[PARAGRAPH:2]Just as the mod title says, this is not just another game clock mod. It is much, much more. This mod provides you the flexibility to most if not all of its different features. There are 12 main variables and one additional variable per era that can be used to configure the Not Just Another Game Clock Mod display information. Those variables are configurable within the BUG Options Screen.

TEXT.English: [H1]Raw Yields[\H1][NEWLINE]by EmperorFool [PARAGRAPH:2]You can enable or disable this mod using the BUG Options screen's (Ctrl-Alt-O) General tab. Simply toggle the "Raw Yield " check box in the first column under "City Screen". You can switch between the display of either Production, Commerce,or Food, by clicking on it's icon in the heard of the Yields display in the upper left quarter of the City Screen.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Raw Yields[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Raw Yields allows you to display a detailed breakdown of each of the tree production type: Commerce, Produce, and Food. To toggle between the modes, click on the icon representing each yield type in the Header. It will give you a detailed breakdown of what each raw yield is, as well as what the actual value is after modifers.[PARAGRAPH:2]It will add up the yields for worked tiles, all tiles in the cities control, or all tiles culturally owned. It will also eliminate the display of 0 values, to help reduce clutter and keep the list of buildings in the city as large as possible. Everything is displayed in a table format, and should be fairly easy to see what the raw yield a city is capable of as soon as you build it, so you know where to focus your improvements, and ensure your city is giving the most possible for your needs.[PARAGRAPH:2]This mod component was based of the original Raw Commerce Mod by Sevo.

TEXT.English: [H1]Reminders[\H1][NEWLINE]by eotinb[PARAGRAPH:2][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]Alt+R[COLOR_REVERT]: Creates a pop up window in which you set the number of turns until the reminder goes off and the text of the reminder. When that turn comes around, your reminder will appear as a message on the screen and in the event log (but only for a few turns). Also an alarm noise will play to get your attention. You can have as many reminders pending as you like. As of now there is no way to eliminate a reminder (other than passing the turn it is set to go off) or any way to view the current reminders. If I get ambitious, I may include these features in a future version.

You can have as many reminders pending as you like. As of now there is no way to eliminate a reminder (other than passing the turn it is set to go off) or any way to view the current reminders. If I get ambitious, I may include these features in a future version.

TEXT.English: [H1]Whip Assistant[\H1][NEWLINE]by EmperorFool[PARAGRAPH:2]Whip Assistant will tell you how many hammers of overflow you will have if you hurry production by sacrificing your population. The overflow you receive is put towards your next build. So, for example, you can whip a library for 2 population with 32 hammer overflow means that it will take 2 of your population, but you will get the library the next turn, plus 32 hammers to whatever you build next.[PARAGRAPH:2]Whip Assistant will also add a counter to the city screen telling you how many turns until the Unhappiness caused by the Whipping, will expire.

TEXT.English: [H1]Wide City Bars[\H1][NEWLINE]by asioasioasio[PARAGRAPH:2]This modification will extend the City Bar by around 25% it's normal size. This will allow for longer names many users experience when using translations of Civilization 4.

TEXT.English: [H1]Better BTS AI[\H1][NEWLINE]v0.78 [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]New User Interface Features[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Holding down SHIFT+ALT and clicking on a leader in the scoreboard toggles your civ's warplan between WARPLAN_PREPARING_TOTAL and NO_WARPLAN. This feature can be used to signal to your vassals that they should begin preparing for war with a particular player as well, allowing them to be much better prepared when you declare. Any warning you can give your vassals will help, but enough time to build one to two units in a city is best. WARNING: Use of this feature is not multiplayer compatible, WARPLANs are not sent across the network since they're otherwise only used by the AI and so it will lead to OOS errors if you have vassals.[PARAGRAPH:2]The scoreboard will show WAR in yellow instead of red when you have declared you are planning a war using the above feature.[PARAGRAPH:2]Added line to contact help text explaining that SHIFT+ALT clicking toggles war preparation plans.[PARAGRAPH:2]Air units can now be set to explore, they use the same explore logic as AI planes and then have additional logic if that doesn't push a mission. Note that planes on auto explore always move at the very beginning of your turn! [PARAGRAPH:2]Better BTS AI is a mod component which improves AI behaviour: [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]War Strategy AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified how closeness is used for determining who to attack, different setting for regular and aggressive AI [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will consider declaring war for resources, weighted towards resources AI doesn't have and plots that are more easily capture [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified city attack targeting by terrain bonuses to consider how important bonus is to AI [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]An AI winning a war no longer automatically accepts offers of capitulation, may continue conquest under a few circumstances [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AIs will no longer declare war on faraway vassals of their neighbors [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If team is losing a land war badly, they will now use defensive area AI in all areas where there is significant enemy presence [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified a losing civs decision to offer capitulation, prior method made capitulation less likely if there were many small capitulated vassals on the map [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Adjusted threshold for offering capitulation based on above change [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now begins accelerating war plan if it has 1.5x as much power as enemy, instead of only accelerating at higher than 2.0x [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]War tactics AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack city stacks will now reduce the distance they travel in enemy territory so the enemy has less time to prepare or hit them with suicide siege [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack stacks with decent initial odds and big troop advantage will skip bombarding and just attack (so enemy can't restock) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack stacks without much bombard power will now prefer to go after cities with low defense modifiers, effect reduced after AI can build bombers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack stacks without much bombard power are a little bolder in attacking city before defenses are lowered to 0, though they will bombard a few turns to make sure bombers and ships can get some shots in [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Loaded transports coming in for an invasion will now usually move outside opponents territory and adjacent tiles to up surprise factor and reduce exposure to attacks before landing [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now beef up border security a little before a war (as if it has terrible relations with neighbor), not enough to give intentions away [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now treats a border with a vassal as pretty safe, regardless of relations [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now prefer to stage attack stacks in coastal cities with transports when running invasion for faster loading into boats [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Created new logic for AI to run assault transports to reinforce its existing positions without building up new full invasion force [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI can now time smaller transport loads to arrive at the same time as bigger invasion stacks [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack city stacks in own cities now wait if enough units are just about to join before heading off to attack [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI puts less weight on minor civ cities when also at war with major civs [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Vassal AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Vassals will now be better prepared to participate when their AI master is planning a war. If their master is a human, they will be probabilistically be a bit better prepared. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Capitulated vassals will now build health improvements more often in cities which need them to help break the population barrier to freedom [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Capitulated vassals will now build culture improvements in more cities with low culture ratings to try to snag more territory and gain their freedom [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]City AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now more likely fill empty transports when enagaged in transcontinental war, making reinforcements and second waves on invasions more likely [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When doing invasions, AI will now be more likely to have cities with free air experience fill vacancies on carriers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When doing invasions, AI will now have cities with high production or free sea experience more often fill needs for aircraft carriers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When doing invasions, if AI has at least 50% of its possible missile capacity it will no longer always build missiles [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Rewrote CvCityAI::AI_isAirDefended so that it considers unit damage, movement, AI type and can also count land units [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Normal workboat build blocked if there's an enemy sea unit camping outside city [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Coastal cities will now build boats as if planning a sea invasion if there is no route to enemy cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Improved handling of building troops to fill transports, unified between coastal and non-coastal cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Non-coastal cities now help fill carriers, missile carriers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]The AI was blocked from building attack troops if it felt it was unable to build good ones, now if it is at war it can build them but with low probability so it can fight back a little early in the game [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now emergency build fighter planes if its air defenses are shot down but it still has lots of bombers and missiles [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If not critical, AI will let cities with high production or free air experience usually build most planes [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Cities with military production bonuses now a bit more likely to build military units [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now always build some assault transports if it has significant overseas colonies to help defend them [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now build reserve sea units to defend its settler transports in later eras [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Reduced construction of escorts that are weaker than the transports they would be escorting (Caravels escorting Galleons primarily) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI coastal cities will now act as if running AREAAI_ASSAULT (ie, doing invasion) if team has war plan against a team it can't reach, not just at war [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Blocked coastal cities from gearing up for naval invasions if enemy team isn't on same water area (for cities on inland lakes in maps with oceans) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI cities on inland lakes which are connected through a bridge city to the ocean are now considered to be on "relevant" water areas, meaning they will now help build navies [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Tweaked logic for production of escorts so the AI builds them faster if it doesn't have any [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Adjusted threshold for construction of missionaries when at war, an AI that is on a roll capturing cities will now be more likely to build missionaries to convert the new cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Added extra logic for panic production of defensive and counter attack units when AI is losing the wars it is in [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will no longer build Galley settler or troop transports when it has access to Carracks or some other transport which can enter ocean tiles (half of fix for Galley->Carrack->Galleon issues) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fix for issue with selection of plots to work which led to tiny per turn production in some large coastal cities due to higher weighting on food. Particularly an issue with coastal cities whose only hammer access is forested plains. AI coastal cities will now produce at least a few hammers when they have enough food. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Production of planes for carriers now happens when AI has empty carriers, independent of whether AI is launch invasion. Should better fill carriers built outside of invasion logic which were often useless before [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Worker AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fix issue where AI would not build workboats to make use of resources in small lakes (was blocked because it felt lake was not relevant militarily) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fixed issue where AI workers would load into a galley with a settler, causing a defenseless settler to freze on empty island [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fixed issue where AI workers responded strongly to temporary commerce/research emphasis decisions (one cause of cottage cycling down) [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Settler AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fixed bug where settlers with no path to city sites on same continent would idle indefinitely and never load on transports [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transports will now only unload settlers who actually have a path to city sites in area [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now has extra encouragement to put cities on water when water access is not ice locked, when ocean is militarily relevant, and if player doesn't have enough coastal cities yet [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now has extra encouragement to put cities on rivers early in the game [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transport full with a settler and workers but no defense now dumps the load, no longer delivers the sitting ducks to remote island/new world alone [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Settler transports which have a settler on board no longer look for other settler to pick up, now explicitly look for extra city defense units (only one settler will load anyway, chasing additional settlers was just a waste of time before) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will not send out new colonists when it is already in financial trouble [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Espionage AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When a spy has waited in a city but has no mission available, they are now more likely to move around and explore instead of sitting [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Revamped desired Espionage rate and priority weighting calculations, AI now always update weights, relations play a larger role [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Neutral priority weighting is now 10 instead of 0, differentiates between [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When AI starts preparing for war against another player they will heavily shift their espionage spending towards that player [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will attempt to gain passive mission levels against adversaries [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now actually load spies onto the spy transport it builds [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Smoothed and rebalanced AI's weighting on espionage yield, previously was either equal to production (!) or 0. This issue caused the overemphasis on spy specialists by governors. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]City govenor weighting of espionage yield now responsive to player's positioning of espionage slider [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Gold AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now has a budget for troop upgrades each turn based on how much gold it wants to have, it won't spend more than this budget on non-critical units when at peace [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now prioritizes upgrading escort ships to same extent as transports [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Tweaks so that AI emphasizes/deemphasizes gold yield in a broader range of circumstances, will help AI and city governors make better choices when doing all out science or culture and also if having money problems. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Civic AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now will more readily change civics in a golden age, acts as if it is spiritual [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Diplomacy AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Removed blanket acceptance of all proposals by secretaries the AI is friends with, now just auto accept less strategic proposals like extra trade routes [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Being friends with secretary now influences civics and other strategic proposals [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI now more likely to defy civic proposals which are bad for it, particularly on Aggressive AI [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Reworked AI voting on forced peace, added thresholds so winning/losing calculations are more meaningful (no longer losing a war in which no units have fought, unless being dogpiled) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]For forced peace proposals, added considerations for whether peace team is winning or losing big [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AIs which are third parties to the war in question may now vote to continue it for selfish reasons (share wars with peace team, are planning to attack peace team) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now only defy forced peace if it is doing quite well in the war, increased use of personality so warmongers are much more likely to defy [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Vassals will now vote for forced war proposal under some circustances. Previously they were blocked from voting for a war they weren't already in since they can't declare war on their own. (Vassals of player to be attacked always vote no still) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now always vote for a forced war proposal against a player they are planning to attack anyway in addition to always voting yes if already at war [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]For forced war vote, replaced blanket check on whether AI doesn't hate victim with roll based on AI's attitude-based peace probability [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Averaging of attitudes of vassals and masters is now done using the more accurate +- attitude value, not the attitude type [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Naval AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified bombard behavior. Priority remains on supporting player's ground troops, if none then consider supporting other troops with common enemy and spreading out stacks to increase reach of blockade. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified and expanded Solver's changes to retreat from city/fort AI to be more specialized for various unit AI types, only move if there's a real threat [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Increased city danger threshold so enemy ships do not runaway so easily [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Damaged ships will stay unless city is highly threatened [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Galleons assigned escort roles before Frigates are available will now change their UnitAI type to assault transport instead of getting stuck in their role after better escorts come along [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transport ships waiting in port will now only unload their cargo during a land war if an enemy city can be reached by land, the player is on the defensive locally, or a stack of enemy units shows up. Increases naval invasions of distant enemies on Pangea maps, sea assaults to complement land assaults. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault flotillas now leave behind empty transports [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault ships now assume cities whose defenses the player can't see are properly defended (previously counted as a single defender). Should make invasions more likely to occur near blockades, attack ships, prior invasions. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now try to break blockades if it has many attack ships in port [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transports will now pickup units stranded on small islands [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transports looking for cargo to pickup now use PUF_isAvailableGroupHeadUnitAIType instead of just counting unit ai types, should stop assault transports from waiting forever for units attached to a settler to load or waiting forever on small islands for units already in their cargo to load [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]EscortAI units will now also shadow settler_sea units when there is nothing else to do [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Added a pathlength consideration to AI_pickup so that mostly loaded flotillas don't sail around the world to pickup one more unit (previously they would have waited trying to load the units they already had on board until someone else came around) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]SettlerSea transports now only run pickup if they're not full (another change necessary since transports no longer try to pickup the units they're already holding) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified CvUnitAI::AI_shadow to optionally ignore units in cities, far away [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Reserve sea units will now prioritize shadowing settler transports out at sea even if they're empty [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack sea units won't run around the world to shadow transports and carriers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Slow escorts (Caravels mainly) will now protect large flotillas instead of doing nothing [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Escorts with nothing to do will now return to the primary area if it's not too far away so that primary area city production decisions take them into consideration [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]If a settler transport is full of workers but has nowhere to take them, it will now dump the cargo if an available settler comes along [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault transports at sea will now wait for escorts, other transports etc that are about to join them [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault transports that aren't full but have enough units for an invasion will now wait one more turn if there are units about to load onboard or group with them [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Improved grouping of AI transports, two groups with multiple transports each can now group together to form one big enough to invade (previously transports could only join a group one at a time, two groups could never merge while carrying cargo or being escorted) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI transports looking for attack city stacks to pick up now require cities to only have at least one dedicated defender, improves AIs ability to pickup troops from prior invasions and island hop [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault transports in port now wait for nearby escorts to arrive before launching invasions [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will now transfer some troops to the new world to conquer barbarian cities if it isn't doing anything else with them [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Reinforcement sized invasions will also now hunt barb cities if civ has no war plans [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Settler, spy and missionary transports that are not full and but have units coming to load now explicitly wait for them instead of going to do pickups somewhere else [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Changes to CvUnitAI::AI_retreatToCity to stop oscillation of naval units into and out of threatened cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Assault transports with cargo no longer move to cities to pickup units which are still being produced (reduces exposure to poaching), won't consider units which were just built in between turns either [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transports which launch an amphibious invasion will now also drop-off any units which remain on board after the invasion (due to winning combat, seige units) in the captured city instead of transporting them back [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Transports no longer attempt to pickup attack city units recovering in recently captured cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Second waves of invasions will now more likely target areas where AI already has captured some cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI transports now scrap or switch UNITAI type if owner can build better transports but unit can't upgrade to them (half of fix for Galley->Carrack->Galleon issues) [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI ocean-capable transport groups now split off galleys [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI galley assault transports which can upgrade now wait in cities to be upgraded [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Air AI[\BOLD] [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Modified and expanded Solver's changes to retreat from city/fort AI to be more specialized for various unit AI types, only move if there's a real threat [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Increased city danger threshold so enemy aircraft do not retreat so easily [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Attack planes in endangered cities will now more likely to airstrike attackers [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Improved code for defense planes in endangered cities so they stay to defend longer and either airstrike or patrol [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Improved efficiency of danger threshold check for ships and planes [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Improved code for moving planes to offensive or defensive bases to take city threat into account [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI bombers will no longer consider basing in undefended forts even if the fort is unthreatened [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI bombers will now consider moving to a city with two defenders (down from requiring 3), change made because of added threat logic and should allow AI to now use almost all of its cities as airbases [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Fixed bug introduced in Unofficial Patch 0.19 causing bombers to skip their turns whenever an interceptor was around [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Many improvements to better handle damaged planes in threatened cities [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Added two functions for defensive airstrikes to make both air defense and offense units more directly aid in defending cities from enemy stacks [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI air defense units wake from airpatrol every turn, re-decide roles/need [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI air defense units now consider how many other air defense units there are in the city and guarantee air defense [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Air defense units with Interceptor promotions now will be more likely to patrol when city is threatened [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Added new function for weighting bases for attack air units with new consideration for supporting offensive stacks and defending endangered cities, plus keeping planes safe from sneak attacks when at peace [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]When at war forts are now more likely to be used as offensive bases, though cities are still preferred [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]AI will
