TEXT.English: [H1]Religions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind mod adds 4 new ancient religions: Amun-Ra, Hellenism, Nagualism and Zoroastrianism. The mod also makes all the religions more unique which means that each religion's building modifiers and religion's commerce rates are different from another religion. The base for these changes has been mostly Eusebius World Religion Revival mod (made for Warlords expansion). [PARAGRAPH:2]Besides making religions more unique, there are couple other changes as well: [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]New religions build Pantheon type of building instead of Cathedral and Pantheons become available earlier than Cathedrals. [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Most religions have now 2 religious Great Wonders [NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET]Some religions can build religious National Wonders.

TEXT.English: [H1]Mapscripts[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind mod adds new terrain type [LINK=TERRAIN_MARSH]Marsh[\LINK] and new terrain feature [LINK=FEATURE_SWAMP]Peat Bog[\LINK]. Because of these terrain changes, the regular mapscripts from Civ 4, Warlords and from Beyond the Sword won't work correctly. For this reason all the default and other custom mapscripts have been disabled and all those mapscripts have been converted to work with Rise of Mankind mod. All the changed mapscripts start with the text "RoM_", if the mapscript you are trying to use does not have this prefix, you might encounter problems when game is generating the map. Some converted mapscripts are still unable to generate Marsh terrain (these require still some python "fixes" before they can place Marsh terrain) but new terrain feature Peat Bog should appear on all maps since it is set to appear also on tundra.[PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind adds 2 new map sizes: Giant and Gigantic. These maps are extra large and should be tried only on high end computers. There are still some issues with these new map sizes, meaning that some mapscripts won't work correctly for these new map sizes and the script won't place terrain correctly - more advanced mapscripts, like Smartmap, can handle these new map sizes without problems - if you encounter problems on Giant and Gigantic mapsizes on certain mapscripts, I recommend using max Huge map size.[PARAGRAPH:2]Basic mapscripts are shown in list when you click Single Player and then Play Now. Advanced mapscripts can be used in Custom Game.

TEXT.English:
[H1]Civics[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind mod overhauls the civic system from Beyond the Sword completely. Starting from version 2.5 the system is based on discussions in Rise of Mankind forum section in www.civfanatics.com (earlier Rise of Mankind used combination of other civic mods). The civic system consists now 7 categories: Government, Power, Society, Economy, Religion, Welfare and Future. At the start players can use the categories from Government up to Welfare and once you reach the future technologies, new future civic options will become available. Each category has 8 civic options, except Future category which has five. The new system is based on organic ideas that can overlap and some of the new options are bit abstract - this increases learning curve but once you have played few games with the new system, you will master it.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Categories:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]GOVERNMENT[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]The ideological basis for the civilization, the executive power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Chiefdom[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a chief or a number of chiefs.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Despotism[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a dictator.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Monarchy[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a hereditary king or emperor.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Democracy[COLOR_REVERT] - Representative democracy. The people elect rulers to either defend their Constitution or to carry out the peoples' wants.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Republic[COLOR_REVERT] - Broad definition, but essentially the state is ruled by a government not ruled by a monarch but where the people themselves installed the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Fascist[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a totalitarian nationalist government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Communist[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by an authoritarian government with the intent of creating a classless society.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Federal[COLOR_REVERT] - State(s) ruled by localized government centers which can create new laws as long as those laws follow the guidelines set by federal government (f.ex. US and EU).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]POWER[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]The dominant sphere of power behind the 'government' choice, sometimes a class of citizenry, sometimes a political institution.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Junta[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a dictator and his closest advisors like family members or military generals.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Nobility[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by the noble class.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Patrician[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by the wealthy class.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Bureaucracy[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by civil servants in specialized departments.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Vassalage[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by the ruler and favoured nobility.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Parliament[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a chamber of many politicians, giving greater power to the legislature. [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Senate[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by a council of fewer, more powerful politicians, giving greater power to the executive.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]President[COLOR_REVERT] - State ruled by one ruler and his/her advisers that is strictly executive, with the legislative branch having lesser power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]SOCIETY[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]The leading sphere of influence within society - sometimes a belief (such as caste) - sometimes a system as in Vassalage, sometimes a social class, proles/bourgeious, sometimes a political preference. They are all based on the evolution of social dynamics in our history.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Tribal[COLOR_
REVERT] - Society values tribal life.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Caste[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values caste system.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Proletariat[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values benefiting the working class.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Bourgeois[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values benefiting the upper classes.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Feudal[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values a rigid social structure (such as Medieval feudal serfdom).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Liberal[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values giving all or most of the people liberty.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Nationalist[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values their country as more important than any other goal.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Marxist[COLOR_REVERT] - Society values trying to achieve equality.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ECONOMY[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]System of economics[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Barter[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy without currency and runs on exchange.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Slavery[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy using barter or currency that uses slavery as a base for production, resource gathering, ETC.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Free Market[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy with a lack of government intervention. So a capitalist or market economy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Mercantile[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy with the intent of exporting more than importing.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Planned[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy that is planned by the government.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Regulated[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy that uses government intervention with the free market to maximize economic growth and weaken recessions. Essentially a mixed economy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Corporatist[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy that relies on many protectionist policies and government regulations put in place to benefit the corporations rather than the consumers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Green[COLOR_REVERT] - Economy where government forces corporations to follow environmental laws.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]RELIGION[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]The political and social basis for your civilization's church and religous institutions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Folklore[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion run by pagan shamans and elder storytellers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Prophets[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion spread by non-partisan disorganized preachers.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Divine Cult[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion run by government and includes worship of the ruler as a god.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Free Church[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion run by a private-run church with immense political power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]State Church[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion run by a government approved church.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Intolerant[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion run by a zealous church intolerant of other religions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Secular[COLOR_REVERT] - Religion is run by a private church with no political power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Atheist[COLOR_REVERT] - Government has banned religion and promotes "atheism"[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]WELFARE[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]The system of welfare provisal, is it personal responsibility? Private enterprise, the church - all have social political repercussions.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Survival[COLOR_REVERT] - No active welfare system. Each member of society cares only about his/her own family's survival.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Charity[COLOR_REVERT] - Unorganized private welfare.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Church[COLOR_REVERT] - Organized welfare run by
the clergy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Public Works[COLOR_REVERT] - Government invests a lot of money in public works such as public infrastructure, as a means to create work.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Private[COLOR_REVERT] - Organized welfare run by private organizations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Corporate[COLOR_REVERT] - Government gives welfare to corporation instead of the people.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Subsidized[COLOR_REVERT] - Private welfare combined with the government giving money to the poor (subsidies).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Socialized[COLOR_REVERT] - Government supplies free welfare to all citizens.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]FUTURE[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]A singular cap style civic, that helps lend a final definition of a civilization's path in the future era.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Supremacy[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Post-Scarcity[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Technocracy[COLOR_REVERT] - Scientists, engineers and other intellectuals have political power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Superhuman[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Paradise[COLOR_REVERT] -

he clergy.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Public Works[COLOR_REVERT] - Government invests a lot of money in public works such as public infrastructure, as a means to create work.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Private[COLOR_REVERT] - Organized welfare run by private organizations.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Corporate[COLOR_REVERT] - Government gives welfare to corporation instead of the people.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Subsidized[COLOR_REVERT] - Private welfare combined with the government giving money to the poor (subsidies).[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Socialized[COLOR_REVERT] - Government supplies free welfare to all citizens.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]FUTURE[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]A singular cap style civic, that helps lend a final definition of a civilization's path in the future era.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Supremacy[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Post-Scarcity[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Technocracy[COLOR_REVERT] - Scientists, engineers and other intellectuals have political power.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Superhuman[COLOR_REVERT] - [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]Paradise[COLOR_REVERT] -

TEXT.English: [H1]Limited Religions[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Limited Religions is a game feature which allows each player to found only one religion. In Rise of Mankind this setting is off by default but if you want to use this feature you can enable it from [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]BUG options[COLOR_REVERT] by pressing [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]CTRL-ALT-O[COLOR_REVERT] and choosing RevDCM option page.

TEXT.English: [H1]Religious Victory[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The mod has a new victory condition for the game called the religious victory. To win with a religious victory, a player must achieve total religious unity and influence through 5 prerequisites (see below). [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]A player must have an official State Religion[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]80% of a player's cities must have the official state religion established.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]All of a player's cities must not have any non-state religions established.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Global religious influence must be at least 75%[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]A player must have built the official State Religion Shrine.

TEXT.English: [H1]Static Leaderheads -module[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind comes with Static Leaderheads module. This module is entirely optional and is off by default. What it does is that it changes all default Beyond the Sword leaderheads (50 of them) to static versions ie. to versions which do not have animations. If enabled this speeds up the load times of leaderheads and game should use less graphical memory so this might help to late era memory allocation faults.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How to use[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The module can be found from folder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules'[COLOR_REVERT]. To enable the module just move folder Static (with its subfolders) to folder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules'[COLOR_REVERT].

TEXT.English: [H1]Civ Specific UnitArtStyles -modules[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Rise of Mankind comes with several Civ Specific Unitarstyles modules. These modules are entirely optional and all of them are on by default. These modules provide alternative civilization specific unit graphics for most unit classes. So far the arstyles have been made for following civilizations: [NEWLINE][NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]America[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Arabia[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Aztec[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Babylon[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Barbarian[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Byzantium[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Carthage[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]China[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Dutch[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]India[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Japan[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Rome[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Russia[NEWLINE][ICON_BULLET]Viking[PARAGRAPH:2]These artstyles aren't complete yet and as you can see most civs do not have yet their own unit artstyle, instead they'll use the default ethnic unitartstyle set for their civilization. Note that disabling these modules reduces the amount of unit graphics the game needs to load and use and thus this may improve game performance.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]How to disable or enable[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2] The modules can be found from folder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules\Custom ArtStyles'[COLOR_REVERT]. To disable the module(s) just move civ specific folders with their subfolders from Custom ArtStyles -folder to folder [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules\Custom ArtStyles'[COLOR_REVERT]. After you have moved the folders and reloaded the mod, the game will skip loading these modules. To enable the modules again, just move them back to the original folder.

TEXT.English: [H1]UN Peacekeeping Forces -module[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This module adds one new National Wonder and several new United Nations' unit classes. This module requires that Diplomatic Victory has been enabled. To build the new unit classes you will need to complete the national wonder [COLOR_BUILDING_TEXT]UN Mission[COLOR_REVERT] first. The units enabled by this wonder are:[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN APC[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Diplomat[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Motorized Infantry[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Fighting Vehicle[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Transport Airplane[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Transport Helicopter[COLOR_REVERT][NEWLINE][TAB][ICON_BULLET][COLOR_UNIT_TEXT]UN Peacekeeper[COLOR_REVERT][PARAGRAPH:2]All of these units are defensive units only and they can not capture cities. They also have hidden nationality so you can defend friendly neighbours during their wars without declaring war to anyone. The module can be disabled by moving UN Mission and all UN units from 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules' folders to 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules'

TEXT.English: [H1]Holy Wars -module[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]This module enhances Christianity religion by adding 3 knightly orders for it. The orders are Hospitaller, Templar and Teutonic Knightly orders. Each of these have building or national wonder and Great Wonder. These buildings are required for training each Order's unit types. The module is disabled by default. The module can be enabled by moving Holy Wars folder from 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules' folder to 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules'

The module can be enabled by moving Holy Wars folder from 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules' folder to 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules'

TEXT.English: [H1]Strategy Overlay[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]Strategy Overlay allows player to plan where he wants to place his next cities by adding colored dots to the desired map plots. To activate Strategy Overlay edit mode, press [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ALT-X[COLOR_REVERT]. Select desired color from the palette on the left and then mouse left button to place a dot to map plot. The plot is surrounded with city radius to give you a clear picture how the land will be used if city is placed on that plot. To remove dot from plot hover your mouse pointer over it and right click. Press [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]ALT-X[COLOR_REVERT] to exit Strategy Overlay edit mode. With [COLOR_HIGHLIGHT_TEXT]CTRL-X[COLOR_REVERT] you can turn on and off the overlay.

TEXT.English:
[H1]Advanced Combat Odds[\H1][NEWLINE][NEWLINE]by PieceOfMind[PARAGRAPH:2]Right from the outset, make sure you understand that all odds in the Advanced Combat Odds display are rounded to 1 or 2 decimal places. Displayed odds of 100.00%, for example, could represent 99.995% or greater meaning the odds are not certain. Similarly, 0.00% does not mean zero odds - just very small odds.[PARAGRAPH:2]There are now four settings for the level of detail you wish to have displayed using this mod: Low, Medium, High and Everything! Medium is the default setting and recommended for most users.[PARAGRAPH:2]Advanced Combat Odds aims to be more accurate, relevant and informative than the original odds calculator. See the included text file for a list of features available at each detail setting.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE][BOLD]What do all the values mean?[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Survival Odds:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These are simple - the odds of both the attacker (green) and defender (red) surviving. Sometimes using units like catapults means the defender will have 100% odds; This is because the attacker cannot kill the defender and must withdraw before dealing a killing blow.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Victory:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The odds of the attacker killing the defender. Also presented on this line is the number of XP the attacker would earn if he wins. At Medium detail and higher, there is an additional value on this line. This value is the average hitpoints of the attacker if he kills the defender.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Withdraw:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These are the odds of a forced withdrawal from combat. Units like catapults and cannons, which have a combat limit, cannot kill a defending unit. Instead they can only damage the defender down to a certain level (eg. 25HP for catapults, 20HP for cannons, 15HP for artillery). The XP a unit earns for withdrawal is 1XP. At the end of this line, the average values of both attacker and defender HP are presented for the withdrawal battle outcome (for Medium detail and higher). Note average defender HP on this line corresponds to the damage limit of the unit you are using to attack.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Retreat:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are using units that have inherent retreat odds or that have earned promotions that give them retreat chances, then this line tells you the probability of your unit retreating. Units will only retreat if they are one hit away from being killed, and only when they are the attacker. The HP value presented on this line (Medium detail and higher) is the number of hitpoints the attacker would have if he were to retreat from the battle injured.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Defeat:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The odds of the attacker being killed by the defender. The XP the defender will earn is displayed, along with the average number of hitpoints the defender will have if he survives combat (Medium detail and higher).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Detailed Attacker HP Outcomes:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]At the High and Everything, these values will be displayed directly under the battle outcomes representing the attacker surviving. For each number of hitpoints the attacker could possibly have, beside it you will find the probability of the unit exiting battle with that many hitpoints. There is also a coloured bar beside each outcome, to help visually identify the scope of the values. Note if there are retreat odds involved, the lowest HP value for the attacker will include the probability of retreat in its odds. Note the sum of all the HP outcomes should be the same as the odds of the attacker surviving.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Detailed Defender HP Outcomes:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Much the same as Attacker HP Outcomes, except for the defender. Note the sum of all these values should be the odds of the defender surviving.[PARAGRAPH:2]Attacker/Defender damager per hit, number of hits required, odds of hits and CombatRatio: A lot of data is displayed on this line. The first two values are the amount of HP damage each of the attacker and defender (respectively) will cause per hit. Then after that, the number of
hits required by each combatant are displayed. In green, is the number of hits required by the attacker to kill the defender or to force the attacker's withdrawal due to a combat limit. In red is the number of hits required for the defender to make to either kill the attacker or to make him retreat. Next, the odds displayed in green are the odds of the attacker for making a hit in each combat round. The defender's odds are just 100% minus this number. Finally on this line is the important value called the CombatRatio or simply R. This value is equal to the attacker's modified combat strength divided by the defender's modified combat strength. This number is important for many reasons - one being that it determines how many XP the attacker and defender can earn from combat. The value R takes both injured units and all combat related modifiers into account (e.g. promotions and defense bonuses).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Average HP: (High detail an above)[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This line simply gives the average hitpoints for each combatant after battle. Unlike the averages presented earlier, these averages include the possibility of the unit dying, so they better reflect the overall outcome of battle.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unharmed:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These odds are very simple. They are the odds of the attacker/defender exiting combat without taking a single hit i.e. unharmed. Units that are already injured are counted as winning unharmed if they don't take damage during the battle.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unrouneded XP:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These values are shown at Everything detail only. These values are rounded down to the nearest whole number, and then forced to be within 1 and 10, to give the actual XP that can be earned by each combatant for killing their opponent. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]XP range:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This line is only shown at Everything detail, and it crams a lot of information on one line. In the middle, it presents the CombatRatio i.e. the R value, and the XP it corresponds to. On either side of it, the CombatRatios that would lead to different number of XP earned are shown. If you increase the value of R (for example, by taking a Combat promotion) then tipping it over the next value will cause your XP earned to drop by 1 point.

Note average defender HP on this line corresponds to the damage limit of the unit you are using to attack.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Retreat:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]If you are using units that have inherent retreat odds or that have earned promotions that give them retreat chances, then this line tells you the probability of your unit retreating. Units will only retreat if they are one hit away from being killed, and only when they are the attacker. The HP value presented on this line (Medium detail and higher) is the number of hitpoints the attacker would have if he were to retreat from the battle injured.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Defeat:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]The odds of the attacker being killed by the defender. The XP the defender will earn is displayed, along with the average number of hitpoints the defender will have if he survives combat (Medium detail and higher).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Detailed Attacker HP Outcomes:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]At the High and Everything, these values will be displayed directly under the battle outcomes representing the attacker surviving. For each number of hitpoints the attacker could possibly have, beside it you will find the probability of the unit exiting battle with that many hitpoints. There is also a coloured bar beside each outcome, to help visually identify the scope of the values. Note if there are retreat odds involved, the lowest HP value for the attacker will include the probability of retreat in its odds. Note the sum of all the HP outcomes should be the same as the odds of the attacker surviving.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Detailed Defender HP Outcomes:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]Much the same as Attacker HP Outcomes, except for the defender. Note the sum of all these values should be the odds of the defender surviving.[PARAGRAPH:2]Attacker/Defender damager per hit, number of hits required, odds of hits and CombatRatio: A lot of data is displayed on this line. The first two values are the amount of HP damage each of the attacker and defender (respectively) will cause per hit. Then after that, the number of
hits required by each combatant are displayed. In green, is the number of hits required by the attacker to kill the defender or to force the attacker's withdrawal due to a combat limit. In red is the number of hits required for the defender to make to either kill the attacker or to make him retreat. Next, the odds displayed in green are the odds of the attacker for making a hit in each combat round. The defender's odds are just 100% minus this number. Finally on this line is the important value called the CombatRatio or simply R. This value is equal to the attacker's modified combat strength divided by the defender's modified combat strength. This number is important for many reasons - one being that it determines how many XP the attacker and defender can earn from combat. The value R takes both injured units and all combat related modifiers into account (e.g. promotions and defense bonuses).[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Average HP: (High detail an above)[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This line simply gives the average hitpoints for each combatant after battle. Unlike the averages presented earlier, these averages include the possibility of the unit dying, so they better reflect the overall outcome of battle.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unharmed:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These odds are very simple. They are the odds of the attacker/defender exiting combat without taking a single hit i.e. unharmed. Units that are already injured are counted as winning unharmed if they don't take damage during the battle.[PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]Unrouneded XP:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]These values are shown at Everything detail only. These values are rounded down to the nearest whole number, and then forced to be within 1 and 10, to give the actual XP that can be earned by each combatant for killing their opponent. [PARAGRAPH:2][BOLD]XP range:[\BOLD][PARAGRAPH:2]This line is only shown at Everything detail, and it crams a lot of information on one line. In the middle, it presents the CombatRatio i.e. the R value, and the XP it corresponds to. On either side of it, the CombatRatios that would lead to different number of XP earned are shown. If you increase the value of R (for example, by taking a Combat promotion) then tipping it over the next value will cause your XP earned to drop by 1 point.

TEXT.English: [H1]Scientific Victory[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]The mod has a new victory condition called the Scientific Victory. To win with a scientific victory, player must reach the last techs in the techtree and then build enough Paradise Gardens to get access to Ascension Gate Great Wonder. Once player has built this wonder, he wins Scientific Victory.

TEXT.English: [H1]No Building Graphics - module[\H1][PARAGRAPH:2]No Building Graphics module allows player to easily disable most regular building graphics in order to save RAM and stress less computer's graphics card. This module is off by default but you can enable it by moving NoBuildingGraphics folder (with its contents) from folder 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Unloaded Modules\Custom Buildings' to folder 'Rise of Mankind\Assets\Modules\Custom Buildings'. If you using low end computer or are experiencing Memory Allocation Faults at some point of the game, you should try enabling this module as with it the game will use less memory.
